title: Citi's "China Desk" Offering Generates Strong Growth Momentum
summary: Shanghai - Citi today reported significant progress for its "China Desk" initiative, first launched in September 2010, reflecting strong client demand for the offering. Under the initiative, Citi has sent senior Chinese bankers to strategic locations around the world to serve the needs of Chinese companies doing business in international markets. After initially opening China Desks in Hong Kong, Singapore, London and New York, Citi has now expanded its China Desks to Dubai, Johannesburg, Nigeria and Algeria.
tag-1: Citi's "China Desk" Offering Generates Strong Growth Momentum
tag-2: Shanghai – Citi today reported significant progress for its "China Desk" initiative, first launched in September 2010, reflecting strong client demand for the offering. Under the initiative, Citi has sent senior Chinese bankers to strategic locations around the world to serve the needs of Chinese companies doing business in international markets. After initially opening China Desks in Hong Kong, Singapore, London and New York, Citi has now expanded its China Desks to Dubai, Johannesburg, Nigeria and Algeria.
tag-3: Henry Zhang, Head of Global Corporate Bank, Citi China, said: "We launched the China Desk initiative recognizing that one of Citi's key strengths, for almost 200 years, is working with institutional clients as they expand overseas. We are well-placed to apply our expertise, our unique global network and our longstanding presence in China to assist Chinese companies to succeed as they continue to do business internationally, and we are delighted with the interest the China Desks have generated from our clients."
tag-4: Since the introduction of China Desks, Citi revenues derived from supporting Chinese clients internationally have risen 30 percent, with demand particularly strong from Chinese companies operating in the energy, telecommunications, information technology and aviation sectors. The China Desks offer clients access to Citi's products and services across its transaction services, markets and global banking platforms, including areas such as foreign exchange, hedging, cash management, trade and treasury services, lending, capital markets issuance and advisory services.
tag-5: Supporting these firms with their treasury and trade and financing needs has proven to be a key element of the services provided by the China Desks. These companies are looking for ways to accelerate their receivables, mitigate cross-border risks, finance working capital and manage their surplus cash. Innovation is also an important area of focus, as customized solutions resonate with many Chinese clients who have complex and special needs.
tag-6: To coincide with the China Desk initiative, Citi has held a number of "China Days" around the world over the course of 2011. These events bring together a range of stakeholders in the local market that have a common interest in discussing matters relating to China and its interaction with the market that the event is held in. These events reflect Citi's commitment to providing its clients with new insights and knowledge that enable them to reach optimal outcomes for their businesses.
tag-7: Citi Citi, the leading global financial services company, has approximately 200 million customer accounts and does business in more than 160 countries and jurisdictions. Citi provides consumers, corporations, governments and institutions with a broad range of financial products and services, including consumer banking and credit, corporate and investment banking, securities brokerage, transaction services, and wealth management.
tag-8: Additional information may be found at www.citigroup.com | Twitter: @Citi | YouTube: www.youtube.com/citi | Blog: http://new.citi.com | Facebook: www.facebook.com/citi | LinkedIn: www.linkedin.com/company/citi
tag-9: Citi China  Citi first established an office in China on May 15, 1902, in Shanghai. In April 2007, Citi was among the first international banks to locally incorporate in China. Citi's locally incorporated entity is known as Citibank (China) Co Ltd, which is wholly owned by Citibank N.A. Today Citi is a leading international bank in China, and has thirteen corporate bank branches - in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, Shenzhen, Tianjin, Chengdu, Hangzhou, Dalian, Chongqing, Guiyang, Nanjing, Changsha and Wuxi- and forty-five consumer bank outlets. With operations in more than 160 countries around the world, Citi is the most global of all international banks in China.
